sp.l: O Eleazer, if thou wert not mine,
I could be happy in my miſery.
Thou art a villain, yet thou art my ſon,
My ſon, and yet a villain; there's a word
Able to make a Fathers heart-ſtrings crack,

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: No more good man.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Strange actions I have heard
have ſometimes wrought ſtrange alterations.
Were it not ſtrange to ſee the Sun go back,
Or borrow light of the unconſtant Moon!
Were it not ſtrange to ſee the Cedar bend,
And do his homage to the lowly shrub
Or to behold the ſtately Lion crouch,
And ſtand in fear of the dejected Lamb;
If none of theſe may yet ſeem ſtrange, behold
A thing more ſtrange; the head muſt ſerve the heel,
The Villain Son muſt ſtand, the Father kneel.
O Gorion! if one ſpark of love be left
In that ingrateful breaſt; or if there be
At leaſt one dram of goodneſs yet remaining,
this act will penetrate his erring ſoul,
Startle his Conſcience, and amaze the will,
Affright the judgement, and divert the plot,
the bloody plot: O! I am loſt with grief,
And do I know not what— And yet it muſt be done:
Come, go with me I ſay, for I will kneel.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.p: Heaven ſend thee comfort in this extaſie.

div.stage: Enter a Carter with his whip, at one door whiſtling, and the Lady Miriams man, Peter, at another.

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.l:
What, brother
• ennel, what a mutren mak'ſt thou here.
sp.p: Nay, nay, nay, I prethee leave thy whewing, and tell me what thou mak'ſt here—apart no! I'le hold a groat I'le make ye leave anon; why firrah, if thou didſt but behold what a pittiful pernicious face thou mak'ſt with whiſtling, thou wouldſt take up ſtones and throw at it.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Take heed thou doſt not whiſtle Peter.
sp.stage: P. O. I thought I ſhould put ye out a tune.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Why prethee?

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: I can hardly endure thy face without it.
If thou ſhouldſt whiſtle, thou wert utterly undone,
I ſhould never for bear throwing at it.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Well contorted efaith boy!

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Nay I can tell ye Peter, for wit and underſtanding I am not regenerate, as they ſay, for my Father had as much knowledge as any man of his underſtanding in the town I woos.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Well, well, well, I have nothing to do with knowledge and underſtanding

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: The thou'rt a • ool Peter.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: I am won of your making then, and indeed it may well be for they ſay won fool makes many: I think I was even w'ye there for the fool.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Excellent good efaith Peter.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Nay I can tell ye, I had a Father too; well, well, I know what
I know; but all's one for 〈◊〉 —um, um: But I prethee boy tell me,
tell me what mak'ſt thou here?
By this hand if thou wil • hor leave whiſtling,
I le throw ſtones.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Why canſt not thou tell what I make here?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Not I as I am a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Why thou hearſt I make muſick bully.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Muſick with a pox, prethee leave making Muſick, and make me an anſwer.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.l: Marry then I will tell thee what I make here:
I am come to follow the wars my boy:
They ſay the new Captains entertain all comers,
And I am all on fire to be at it.
O—methinks I could ſo pepper thee now.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Oh—oh—prethee hold, or elſe I ſhall need to be ſalted too:
But efaith boy, art in earneſt? if thou beeſt, ſhake hands, ſhake hands.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Why thou art not run away from thy Lady too, art?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: No—but I am ſent of an everlaſting Errand, and will leave the anſwer to my Executors: I'me for puſh a pike boy.

sp.speaker: Pen.
sp.p: Stand cloſe, ſtand cloſe, here come, the Captains.

div.stage: Enter Eleazer, Skimeon, and Zareck with a Paper in his hand.

sp.speaker: Elea.
sp.l: The Commons are in arms againſt us Skimeon,
And reſolutely take our Fathers part;
Yet he, I hear, gives no allowance too't,
But rhinks with fair perſwaſions to prevail:
But we are arm'd with reſolution.

sp.speaker: Sk.
sp.l: We muſt be wiſe my Lord; thoſe aged hairs
Are taught by long experience to intrap
our younger brains; and this may be a plot
to take us at' advantage.
Therefore my Lord, in time let me adviſe
that we encreaſe our forces ſpeedily:
Let us make know • the Proclamation.

sp.speaker: Elea.
sp.p: Read the •• ntents of it once again.

div.stage: Zareck reads. Whoſoever liſteth to be rid from the bondage of his Maſter, or hath any injury in his Countrey; or what ſervant ſoever deſireth to beſet at liberty; or who ſo cannot abide the rule of his father or his mother; all that be in debate, and stand in fear of their Creditors, or fear the Iews for shedding innocent blood▪ If there be any man that is accuſed of any notorious crime, & in danger therefore: To be short, whoſoever i • diſpoſed to rob, to haunt Whores, to murder, and to live freely at other mens cost, let him come to me, and I will relieve him.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: O rare! I am raviſhed, I am raviſhed, the wenches, the w • nches boy

sp.speaker: Elea.
sp.l: I do not like the Proclamation,
the ſubject ſounds too harſh, and will beget
Diſtractions in the graver Citizens.

sp.speaker: Skim.
sp.l: Death, what need we care for that,
So we be ſtrong for oppoſition.

sp.speaker: Elea.
sp.l: Delays are dangerous, and we may be ſurpriz'd
Indeed upon the ſudden: well—let it be done,
But in thy Name, for I muſt ſeem to be
Vpright and zealous for their liberty.

div.stage: Enter the High Prieſt and Gorion, the High Prieſt kneels.

sp.speaker: Ananias,
sp.l: Behold young man, thy aged Father kneels;
And knnels to thee, even unto thee his Son,
And begs with tears, with tears of bitterneſs,
the ranſom of thy ſoul, and of the State,
Both loſt for ever, ever loſt if thou perſiſt.

sp.speaker: Elea.
sp.p: Patience defend me, or I ſhall be o'recom.

sp.speaker: Sk.
sp.p: Take heed ye be not caught.

sp.speaker: Elea.
sp.l: Caught! is't poſſible for man to view this ſight,
this moſt prodigious ſight, and not be caught?
O Heavens! Did I not hear him ſay a was my Father?
sp.stage: Go this paſſion I hope, wil work ſome good effect. the Carter comes.
sp.l: Have I not heared him beg, and ſeen him kneel?
Had a been Jewries ſlave, a could have done no more.
Is't poſſible theſe Rivolets of blood ſhould flow
From ſuch a Fountain. Come hither fellow.
Time and Maturity do ſeem to ſay
thou mayeſt have been a Father to a Son:
tell me, hadſt thou e're a ſon?

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.p: Had, I, and have too, an't like your Worſhip, or chood be zorry.

sp.speaker: Elea.
sp.l: The power of Nature works as ſtrong in thee
As in thy Prince; thou lov'ſt him too, I know.

sp.speaker: Cart.
sp.p: By th'maſs I zee your Worſhip's vilely cunning: I do indeed.

sp.speaker: Elea.
sp.l: Couldſt thou afford upon ſome weighty cauſe,
(Suppoſe to ſave thy life) to kneel unto thy ſon?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Kads nails, kneel, I ſcorn that eſaith,
Chil make the Looby kneel to me, chil warrant him.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.l: Come hither; ſeeſt thou this old man? Car. Ay,
Canſt thou believe this man to be my Father?

sp.speaker: C.
sp.p: Vather ketha, no by my troth not I.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.l: Vp thou decrepped lump of vanity.
thou baſe impoſtor that wouldſt cheat the world
With a ſuppoſed Name; thou beaſtly ſhame
Of Age and Honour, thou indignity
Vnto thy ſelf, and thy Poſterity.
Come, come, diſrobe thy ſelf, I ſay, and yeild
sp.stage: Whilſt he ſpeaks, he diſrobes him.
sp.l: theſe ornaments to him that ſcorns to kneel:
Here fellow, put um of • ; put um on, I ſay, for I will have it ſo.
Let our Proclamation be publiſht.

sp.speaker: Za.
sp.p: It ſhall my Lord.

div.stage: Exit Elea. Skim. and Zareck at one door, and Anna. & Gor. at the other, weeping, and after them the Carter whiſtling

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: St Pennel, 'ſt Pennel.
The heighth of his preſerment will not let him anſwer me,
Well, I am aſtoniſhed to think what honor I ſhall come too.

div.head: Incipit Actus Quartus.

sp.speaker: Titus.
sp.l: NOw fellow-Souldiers, what? Methinks ye look
Not ſmiling on Veſpatians Son.
Let not the miſs of your old Captain ſtrike
Your manly hearts with grief: Come, come let me
See your cheerful countenances ſpeak
My hearty welcome; Courage noble friends,
For know, there's not a dram of worth infus'd
Within Veſpatians noble loins, but lives
Inveſted here: theſe luſty Roman veins
Swell high as ere did his, with hopeful pride
Of happy victory; this loyal breſt
Harbours a heart as full of Clemency
If gently ſought unto; but ſlighted once,
the daring Lyon harbours one more mild,
More merciful the I▪ I tell ye Lords,
I'le not expect more duty from your hands,
then my deſerving actions truly weigh'd,
Shall juſtly challenge: And be thus aſſur'd,
My aged Father thus far Ile out-do,
there's not a ti • tle of his former promiſes
to either here, but ſhall by me be crown'd
With fair performance.
To witneſs which, we give you joint Command
And Martial Pow'r, as next unto our ſelf.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: My gracious Lord, the beſt of my endeavours
Shall ſtrive to merit what your noble hand
Hath now conferr'd; my hearts beſt blood my Lord
Shall ſeal my faithful proteſtation.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.l: My actions, my good Lord, ſhall better ſpeak
My humble th • nks, then my unskilful phraſe:
Mean time your Lordſhips pardon for my ſilence.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: Tis well: Now I muſt tell ye Lords,
As I have ript my heart to let you ſee
My lifes Compendium. I expect that you
Should ſhape your actions to deſerve my love:
For I muſt tell ye Lords, 'tis not a formal ſhew
of gilded words that can perſwade me ſo:
Let me behold your brave attempts purſue
Imperious victory through ſeas of blood;
Your panting ſouls in midſt of Maſſacre,
thirſt after Honour, till the reaking blade
cry, 'tis enough.
Have ye not ſeen when in a bloody fray
My Noble Father hath been left alone,
Alone, begirt with ranks of Enemies,
Whoſe ſtrong Batalio's kept all reſcue from him:
How then, even then when horror infinite
Stood gazing on him with a grim aſpect,
How then (I ſay) his daring countenance
Stood in defiance of them all at once:
How the more danger, ſtill the more he durſt,
Like a ſtrange Maſtiff fiercely ſet upon
by mungril Curs in number ten to one,
With angry teeth, and courage bravely bold,
A ſnarles, and ſnaps; now this, now that doth bite,
And ſtoutly ſtill maintains the unequal fight
with equal fury, till the bawling cur • es
be quite diſperſt: So he,
but with ſuch Kingly awful Majesty,
as if in midſt of this confuſion
A found but ſport of recreation.
Such and ſo daring muſt you be my Lords,
to gain my love, and win your countrey honor.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.l: My Lord, our lives & Fortunes weigh'd with either,
We prize at nothing; nor can we deſire
more felicity then to enjoy
the leaſt of either.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: My honored Lord, your moſt exact command
will teach us Valour had we ne're been, train'd
in Martial Diſcipline.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: I like your anſwers wel, ſaving that yours Valerio,
• avours too much of • lattery—and yet
upon life thou art not that way guilty.
And truſt me ſouldiers I am confident
Your words and actions will in all points ſympathize:
But we trifle time, and moſt redeem it
by a ſtrict ſurveigh of our proceedings.

sp.speaker: Ie.
sp.l: From great Veſpatian my moſt honor'd Lord,
I come to do thee humble ſervice.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: Now by my life thou it welcome, welcome worthy friends
Our Royal Father ne'er could ſend a man
More deer in our affection.
Thou com'ſt as we could wiſh thee, Ioſeph;
to morrow we intend to parley with Ieruſalem;
thy friendly preſence may perchance perſwade
thy Countreymen to yeild ſubjection:
If they refuſe, by the Majeſtick power
Of mighty Ceſar's ſacred Diadem,
I'le ſcourge their pride with ſuch ſeverity,
ſhall make the Rebels curſe their miſery.
Come my endeared friend.
The three ſeditious Captains are at odds,
Each hunts the other's lifes yet all do bear
A fair pretence of friendſhip to each other;
Each ſeeks for ſoveraignty; whilſt, Sinon, I
With proteſtations of integrity
And zealous love, do fairly cloſe with all;
For being friends to all in time of league,
'twill be a riddle to the wiſeſt pate,
Whoſe love I prized moſt; then I proteſt
With what obſequious care and ••• ling pains,
My wits are wearied to deſign a plo •
Whoſe wary circumſtances may diſcry
All ſhew of falſhood in the enterprize,
to trip the heels of either enemy;
then ſhew the time, the place, the manner how
to do't: O I am tickled with the fine conceit.
My Father in a fair and good e • tate,
Was by theſe Rebels rob'd and ſpoil'd of all,
And I his ſon left naked to the world,
poor and dejected, till my working brain
Projected this employment to relieve me;
Since when, I have been buſied for revenge:
O how methinks that very word Revenge,
Allaies the fury of my diſcontent!
But ſoft; 'tis much about the time they ſhould be here:
I will withdraw my ſelf.
I muſt be wiſe, and cloath my pleaſing phraſe,
With fair pretence of peace and amity.
The bluſtring wind commands with angry brow,
The toiling travellier to leave his Cloak;
the ſtorm encreaſes, but the pelting man
ſtill gripes it faſter, till the pleaſing Sun
By gentle rayes intreats him lay it down.
sp.stage: Enter L. Jehochanan and L. Skimeon

sp.speaker: Ieho.
sp.p: Good morrow to the Lord Eleazer.
sp.stage: A tubla ſet, and Zareck ſtands behind the Arras.

sp.speaker: Elea.
sp.l: Welcome Iehochanan, welcome noble friends,
Come, ſit we down, and each man freely ſpeak
His cauſe of grievance: Ah my worthy friends,
Diſſention is amongſt us: Vpon my life I dare
preſume there is ſome ſtrange miſtake,
For elſe it cannot be that we ſhould differ.

sp.speaker: Ie.
sp.l: Some ſtrange miſtake? Indeed my Lord 'twas ſtrange
Your Lordſhip ſhould miſtake your ſelf ſo much,
And us your friends (your friends! nay more my Lord, then friends,
For friends are formal now:) the ſtrength of your deſigns:
To ſend to us a publike meſſenger
to ſummon us upon command to be
Attendants on your Lordſhips pleaſure!
My Lord, this was not fair nor friendly.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.l: Not fair my Lords, nor friendly! which of you
that ſtood in equal terms of honor with my ſelf,
Woo'd loſe one tittle of that Dignity
that fairly rank't this ſtate and quality •
Was it for me to ſay, I woo'd intre • t •
Was not the Meſſage publike?
Had it been private, you ſhould then have ſeen
My fair reſpect, and friendly love to either.
But, as it was my Lord—

sp.speaker: L. Skim.
sp.l: Nay, then I muſt have leave to tell ye Sir,
Your Honour ſwells too high, and muſt be qualifi'd
In equal terms of Honor with your ſelf:
My Lord, I dare affirm thus Simeon ſtands
In equal terms of honour with your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Elea.
sp.p: How's that?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Nay good my Lord, your Father's yet alive,
And you are then a private man 〈◊〉 we.

sp.speaker: Elea.
sp.l: This—is in jeſt, to ſee how I can poize
A Friends affection, or perchance—totry the bent of mine.

sp.speaker: Sim
sp.l: Your Honour may do we •• to paſs i • ſo,
Or elſe, perchance your Lordſhip may be angry.
And then—how much your helth may be impair'd
With ſuch diſtemper, may perhaps—

sp.speaker: Elea.
sp.l: No more.
I was not wont to be ridiculous:
Nor did I come to hear ſuch airy talk.
If this be earneſt, let me hear who dares
pronounc'tagen.

sp.speaker: Ie.
sp.l: Who dares! that brave reflects on me,
that dare ſtand up ſpurn at that, and thee.

sp.p: Is't poſſible!

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Iehochanan, thou doſt me open wrong to intercept me:
The cauſe was mine; to me it did belong
to give an anſwer. Wer't thou not who thou art,
I ſhould not take this well.

sp.speaker: Ie.
sp.l: Simeon, I am as deep engag'd as thou,
And will have leave to prize mine Honor higheſt.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: And will have leave!

sp.speaker: Ie.
sp.p: I ſay, and will have leave, and ſay't agen.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Death, thou dar'ſt not ſay't agen.

sp.speaker: Ie.
sp.p: Dare not!

sp.speaker: Elea.
sp.l: I do command ye ceaſe
For ſhame give o're this raſh behaviour:
Is this a time to broach a Faction,
When Ceſars ſon has conquer'd Galile • ,
And now is marching to Ieruſalem

sp.speaker: Ie.
sp.l: Command thy ſlaves, proud man, for I am free,
And will command my ſelf.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: Villain.

sp.speaker: Ie.
sp.p: Thou lyeſt.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: O my inraged ſould, muſt I endure all this?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: All this and more, thou muſt endure me too.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: Muſt Simeon?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: I muſt I ſay, and ſhall:
Couldſt thou dart lightnings from thy countenance,
Thus woo'd I meet thee, and out-face thee thus.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: O I am loſt in rage, and can endure no longer.

stage.hi: They draw, and a trumpet ſoun •• from within.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: From Ceſar's ſons, brave Lords, I come to ſay
He offers parley to Jeruſalem:
The time prefixt is the next morning ſun.

sp.speaker: Elea.
sp.p: Go tell thy Maſter we accept it.

sp.speaker: H.
sp.p: I ſhall return your anſwer.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.l: This is no time to ſight, nor will I now
Stand to defend mine honor: But ſtay,
before we ſheath our weapons let us ſwear
Howe're our private quarrel may proceed,
That we will ſtill maintain each other's part
Againſt Veſpaian's ſon.

sp.speaker: Both:
sp.p: We are content.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.l: Your hands.
By a true ſouldiers Honour we do ſwear,
Fairly to friend each other in the field,
And jointly to oppoſe Veſpatian.

sp.speaker: Both:
sp.p: We ſwear to do't.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.l: The ſame ſwear I.
I ſhall expect you both to morrow early.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: We will not miſs the hour

sp.speaker: Za.
sp.l: The Furies are broke looſe, if either fall,
Zarech may riſe to be a General.

div.stage: Enter Perter with a Sword and Buckler, leading Gorion manicled with an halter about his neck, apparel'd in a Canvaſe ſuit.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Come, come ſir, come away, ſir, come away.

sp.speaker: G.
sp.l: Nay, prethee friend be not ſo rigorous,
Give me a little time to breathe a while.

sp.speaker: Pet
sp.l: Breathe a while! I, I, I'le breathe ye, I warrant ye.
Come, come follow me, follow me, I ſay,
Ye ſhall want for no breathing.

sp.speaker: Go.
sp.l: Inhumane wretch, I cannot follow thee:
Thou haſt already wearied out my limbs
With thy ingrateful uſage.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Nay, nay, nay ſir, all's one for that,
Limbs, or not limbs; I ſay, Folllow me.

div.stage: Beat Drom within, and enter Titus, Joſeph, Vallerio and Nicanor at one door, and the three Captains at the other, and after them Peter, leading old Gorion in the Halter.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Come forward I ſay, a comes like a, Bear to the ſtake.

sp.speaker: Titus.
sp.p: What means this ſpectacle of miſery?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: O Titus, 'tis my Father.
Wert thou enthral'd in more captivity,
Thus low would Ioſeph bow to do thee honor.
I never felt my ſelf ſo far ſurpriz'd
With ſudden paſſion; Nature is or'e charg'd,
And fain woo'd have ſome vent. I fear
I ſhall forget my ſelf: • ye Ioſeph, fie,
Art thou a ſouldier? So—now the ſtream is turn'd.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.p: Now my brave Lords of Jewry, which of you ſtands chief Commander in this bold Rebellion?

sp.speaker: Elea.
sp.p: Rebellion, Titus!

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Speak that word agen,
And Simeon dares reply that Titus lyes.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: Should Titus ſpeak't agen, 'twere ſtill the ſame,
Nor is it leſs ſpoke once,

sp.speaker: Ie.
sp.l: Then know bold Roman, Jewries ſons are free,
And ſcorn to bend to Ceſar, or to thee

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.p: The ſturdy ſtick that will not bend, muſt break.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: But not with Titus Arm, nor Ceſar too.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: A • deareſt countreymen, I come not here
to lift mine arm againſt Jeruſalem,
But to lament it, Lords; for well I know,
the heavens have fore-decreed your overthrow:
The great Caldeans Golden Head is laid,
the mighty Perſians ſilver Arms are lopt;
the Grecians thighs of braſs are broken down:
What's then remaining but thoſe Iron Legs
On which the ſturdy Roman Empire ſtands,
And ſtamps the World to Powder: Ah my Lords
Will ye contend with Fa • e?

sp.speaker: Iehoc.
sp.l: Peace thou baſe coward, that to ſave thy life
Haſt loſt thine honor.
Thou com'ſt with fawning zeal to beg for mercy.

sp.speaker: Ioſeph.
sp.l: To beg for mercy! then mercy ne're protect me.
Forgive me Heaven, that I am forc't to draw
My ſword againſt my ſelf, my Native countreymen.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: Now by my life they come to brave me here.
Rebels, thoſe lordly hearts of yours ſhall bleed;
By all the Gods they ſhall—
Deliver up that aged priſoner,
Or by the Roman Powers ye ſhall repent it.

sp.speaker: Schim.
sp.p: Not for the Roman Crown.

sp.speaker: Elea.
sp.l: Lead him away to torture.
Come, come, come away ſir, I'le tickle him with tortures.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: O my diſtreſſed Fate!

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: Villains, there's not a torture you inflict
Vpon thoſe aged limbs, but I'le return
With millions on your own.

div.stage: Beat Droms, and they fight within; then enter Joſeph and fights with Eleazer, and exeunt. Enter Valerio and fights with Jehoc. and exeunt. Enter Nicanor, fights with Simeon, and exeunt: The three ſeditious are repulst: then enter Titus, and meets with Eleazer, they fight: then enter Jehoc. and Simeon at ſeveral Doors: Titus fights with the three: Eleazer cryes, kill him: Jehochanan, take him alive: Simeon cryes the ſecond time, kill him: Jehochanan, take him alive. Eleazer the third time kill him: Jehochanan, take him alive. Titus makes way through them wounded, and eſcapes.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: Death and the Devil, why did ye let him ſcape?

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: O we are finely cheated of the booty,
And ſhall be laught to ſcorn: Death, I could tear my fleſh.

sp.speaker: Ie.
sp.l: Stand ye to beat the air with idle words?
Let's follow cloſe, and find him out agen.
Diſperſe your ſelves, and follow.
Call ye this Honour? a pox of honor,
Give me honeſty, down-right honeſty!
Souns, break ones head, and give him no warning!
I woo'd not have Honor come ſo faſt upon me neither.
Im'e pepperd with a vengeance: Farewel Honor,
Ile to my Lady agen.

div.stage: Enter Titus wounded: Ioſephus, Valerio, Nicanor, follow.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: How fares my Lord?

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: Well my Ioſephus, truſt me, paſſing well:
'tis Titus glory to be bath'd in blood:
Now by mine Honor Ioſeph, I am glad
to ſee ſuch valour in thy Countrey-men:
the charge was hot, and bravely ſeconded.
Didſt thou not ſee where I was forc't to fight,
to man the Front, that then began recoile.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: My Lord I did.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: There my brave Lords, mine Honor lay at ſtake,
there was I round begirt with Enemies,
and muſt be ranſomed by mine own deſert:
O my Valerio! then I call'd to mind
the great Veſpatian: the Tiberius;
then mighty Julius: and then—
Arm'd with diſdain and envy, I aſſail'd
the ſtout Jehochanan, then Skimeon,
then Lordly Eleazer, then all; and then
Stood all their bold repulſes back agen.
There I receiv'd theſe wounds; and then, at laſt
Rapt into rage with fury and revenge,
Sweating, and bleeding, in deſpight of all
this arm maintain'd me ſtill a General.
But now no more of this:
A more convenient time ſhal fitter ſerve
For this diſcourſe. Come worthy Souldier:
My wounds are ſtiff, I muſt retire my ſelf.
sp.stage: Enter L. Eleazer with his Rapier drawn.
sp.l: The glorious prey is loſt:
Now Eleazer, to thy other buſineſs.
I do remember wel, a ſed, my father was alive:
And then—as if my fathers life were my diſgrace,
A ſlighted me with ſcorn—It muſt be ſo,
My father muſt not live: I am reſolv'd.
A pair of pretious Villains! By this light
I laugh to think how • inely they are cheated.
The Lordly Eleazer woo'd be King;
And ſo woo'd Simeon too. Both aim at me:
But I wil live in ſpight of policy.
The game is ended, and the Deer eſcap't;
the night draws on apace, and I am hurt.

sp.speaker: Elea.
sp.l: The time's within this hour: make haſte, I ſay,
And fit thy ſelf with inſtruments of death,
Smal pocket-daggers. But be ſure thou haſt
A ſpecial care that no o're reaching eye
Detect the plot.
Then with a cloak of ſeeming ſanctity,
Deject behaviour, viſage meanly ſad,
Eies full of tears; but heart replete with blood:
Low bending to my aged father; Say—
What thy more wary wits ſhall think upon:
But on thy life take heed thou fail not.

sp.speaker: Zar.
sp.p: Not for the world.

sp.speaker: Elea.
sp.l: The time draws on apace they ſhould be here:
I muſt diſarm my ſelf and wait their coming.
Theres ſomething troubles me, all is not well within.
I would not ſee him fall: and yet I muſt.
O Eleazer—but I forget my ſelf:

div.stage:
A noiſe of ſtill muſick; and Enter the high Prieſt with attendants, Guards, and Quireſters: they ſing. An Alter and Tapers ſet:
See thoſe buildings where once thy glorie liv'd in,
with heavenly eſſence:
See how it droopeth, and how nakedly it looketh
Without thy preſence:
Hark how thy captive people mourn
With heavy moaning,
and grevious groaning,
For thy being abſent,
And for the heathens ſcorn:
Becauſe thy people are by thee forlorn.
See thoſe tapers, which once enflam'd thoſe vapours
Of our ſweet Peace.
See thoſe places, where we once injoy'd thoſe graces,
Which now do ceaſe.
O See the Altar whereas we
Enjoy'd thoſe bliſſes,
With heavenly kiſſes
From thy free love,
And from thy Clemency:
Whilſt we did ſing to thee mellodiouſly:

sp.speaker: H. P.
sp.p: leave us to our Devotion.
Enter Za. he bowes to the high Prieſt, and declares by ſig • s his ſons ſubmiſſion: he lifts up his hands in token of Thankfulneſs, and weeps.

sp.speaker: H. P.
sp.p: Thou comſt with happie news: go call him in.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: Ah my much wronged Father!

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: This is beyond my hopes: ſtand up young man:
Heaven give thee pardon for thy great offence.
Where are thy confederates?

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: I would not be o're. heard.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Diſmiſs the guard there, we would be private.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.l: My Lord, I have a ſecret to diſcloſe,
sp.stage: Za. looks if none be coming in.
sp.l: Of ſuch importance, that I fear—

sp.speaker: A.
sp.l: I will not be diſturb'd, what ere it be.
For heavens love let me ha'te.

sp.speaker: Za.
sp.p: Thou haſt thine own deſire

sp.speaker: Za.
sp.p: Tis done.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: Tis bravely done: I will reward the Zareck.

sp.speaker: Z.
sp.p: Tuſh, I am happie in the fine exploit.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.l: Now for the crafty cloſe,
sp.stage: puts the dagger into his hand.
sp.l: Conveigh this inſtrument into his hand.
Be brief, be brief, then it may be ſuppoſ'd
A did this bloody act upon himſelf.

sp.speaker: Atten.
sp.l: My Lord—ha!—Murder'd;
Curſe on that wretched hand that did it:
But ſee—O ſee! a gripes the dagger faſt
That gave the wound—I am amaz'd
And know not what to think.
Come let us bear him hence.

div.l: Horror, confuſion, hunger, plague and Death
Have ſeiz'd our Sacred ſtreets, my fainting breath!
Fails me to give the ſad relation
Of ſad Judea's deſolation.
Suppoſe the famine now to grow extream,
Within the City walls; The hungry dream
Of food, but taſt it not, a Cab is ſold
Of noiſom dung for thrice the weight in Gold?
A bloody Sword hangs blazing in the Sky?
A Strange and uncouth voice was heard to cry,
Come, let's away from hence? the Iron gate
Ope's of it ſelf to let in Jewries fate:
To tell ye more my aking heart would break,
The ſad Cataſtrophe let action ſpeak.
The famine is extream;
And will be guile us of our lives and honors.
div.stage: Muſick, and the Lady Miriam Sings In her Chamber.
div.l: Hark—hark—give ear a while and liſten.
div.stage: when the Muſick has plaid a while she Sings

The Song
Weep, O weep, mine eyes, a flood of tears:
Break, O break, my heart, with endleſs feares:
Fly hence, fly hence, my ſoul, from ſuch ſad grief;
Then weeping ſing, and ſinging weep to ſee
Such pretious comfort in thy miſery.

sp.speaker: Ie.
sp.l: This is the Lady Miriam,
Shee's rich, ſhee's rich, exceeding rich
And may perhaps have ſome proviſion left,
I'le in and rifle her.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Ay me, the Lord Iehocanan:
I fear ſome violence.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Who knocks there?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: keep faſt the door.

sp.speaker: Ie.
sp.l: Ope the door Sirrah, or Ile break it ope.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Marry Sir and Ile break your pate then.
sp.stage: Breaks ope the door, and goes in.
sp.l: Wars, or not wars, all • one for that,
For honor will find me out, I ſee;
I am not ſo good as my word, hee's better than his,
For he has broke the door, and my pate too.
But I'le in and ſave my Lady from raviſhing,
What ere comes on't:
If I take him at it, I'le ſo pepper him.

div.stage: Enter Iehochanan with a wallet, dragging The Lady by the hair, and her little Son following weeping.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Now good my Lord even on my knees I beg:
Vſe not my mother ſo unkindly.

sp.speaker: Ie.
sp.l: Peace brawling brat;
Confeſs, confeſs I ſay, I know this is not all,
Thou haſt conceal'd thy beſt proviſion

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: If there be truth in heaven I have no more,
Ah gentle Sir, for pitie take not all,
Leave me one loaf to keep my little one.

sp.speaker: Ie.
sp.p: Not a bit, bold begger.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.l: Good mother weep no more.
My Lady has ſent me to get wormes?
But the wormes are more liker for to get me
Marry I think if they had me and could ſpeak,
They'd curſe the Cook that ſent u'm ſuch a break-faſt;
For I am ſo impenirrable for want of moiſture,
They had better Seize upon a ſtarv'd Vſerer by far:
I have obſerv'd of late a ſeeming ſhow
Of ſome diſtempers in Lord Eleazer:
His lookes are wild and ſtareing: ſomething ſure
Does ſtrangely trouble him.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.l: That's the Captains man that broke my pate.
And rob'd my Lady: now is he ſtudying
Whoſe throat he ſhall cut next; I'de beſt be gone,
I'me peſtilence affraid of him.

sp.speaker: Za.
sp.p: • erchance the murder of his Father troubles him.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: A talkes of murder already.

sp.speaker: Za.
sp.l: If it be ſo, I hope 'twill make him mad,
And I ſhall be reveng'd—What followes that?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: A has ſpi'd mee, I muſt ſtand too't now.

sp.speaker: Za.
sp.p: What art thou?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: What am I; Why I am hungry, very hungry:
So hungry, that I could eat my fleſh,
If I had any fleſh to eat.

sp.speaker: Za.
sp.l: You are very pleaſant, Sir.
Does the muſick of the time, cauſe your wits to daunce.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Ye ſay right, Sir. If any part of me daunce, it is my brains, for they are alwayes in action: my legs are far enough from't I me ſure.

sp.speaker: Za.
sp.p: Whither art thou going?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: No wither, ye ſee, I ſtand ſtill:
I think your wits are daunc't out of your head.

sp.speaker: Za.
sp.p: Whither wert thou going?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: The man's mad ſure: why hither, was I not?

sp.speaker: Za.
sp.p: Excellent, Ifaith wither wilt thou go?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Marry they were wiſe could tell that;
I will go whither my legs will carry me:
Marry how far that is I cannot tell;
For I am altogether for the Carriers pace,
I can neither amble, nor trot now.

sp.speaker: Za.
sp.l: How accurately the knave anſwers;
Tis hunger ſure has made his wits ſo nimble.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Ye're in the right Sir.
For a ſpare diet, ſaies your Philoſopher,
Makes a man fit for ſtudy,
But ſure a meant to get more vittails.

sp.speaker: Za.
sp.p: Better and better—fellow, what's thy buſineſs▪

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: What a queſtion's that now?
Why look on my P • iſ • o my, and read it there.

sp.speaker: Za,
sp.p: I'ſt written in thy fore-head, knave?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: No, but 'tis written a both ſides my face.

sp.speaker: Z.
sp.p: Extremity of hunger ſure has made him mad:

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: No, no, no Sir; No ſuch matter:
Why hark ye Sir, hark ye; don't you know me?

sp.speaker: Za.
sp.p: Not I, by this Light.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: I cannot much blame ye, for I hardly know my ſelf;
But if I had ne're known your Lord, ye might a knowen me better.

sp.speaker: Za.
sp.p: Sure that fellow was born with Riddles in's mouth.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: Fare ye well Sir, fare ye well:
My Lady ſaid I ſhould get ſomething, though I ſtaid all night:
But I'me more liker to ſtay till dooms-day, for I think I ſhan't live
Till morning; fare ye well Sir.

sp.speaker: Za.
sp.l: This is ſure the Lady Miriams man,
Whom Lord Iehochanan hath lately rifled:
Here Comes the Lord Eleazer, I will withdraw.

sp.speaker: Elea.
sp.l: Cozen'd and cheated, gull'd and fool'd I am:
O man, man, man moſt miſerable!
How truly vain,
How abſolutely baſe,
Are thy loſt actions? yet how infinite
The Se • s of ſorrow that thou wadeſt through,
To make thee miſerable.
Ere thy polluted face was yet produc't,
To face of heaven, the wofull womb foretold
With griping throws thy native wretchedneſs:
And when thou wert brought forth, what worlds of care
And greif, and pains the tender mother takes
To bring thee up! what tedious daies and nights
Are thrown away upon thine infant age:
Then—when thy fruitfull branches bear the buds
Of hopefull youth when underſtanding blooms
The beautious bloſſoms of a riper wit:
VVhat daies, and nights, and hours, and minutes ſpent
On tedious papers, whoſe enigma's dull
The ſlender judgement of the youthfull brain
Till when—Maturity proclaims thee man
Then, loomes this goodly veſſel on the main
Of mutabilitie, with all the ſails
Of honour ſwelling high. But ſee—O ſee—
A ſable cloud of ſin with angry brow •
Threatens diſtruction, now the Venoms burſt:
Down with the main, ſails ere the guſt approach,
Alas, 'tis now too late, all's over whelm'd,
Turn'd upſide down, the pre • ious lading loſt,
The ſhipwrack't ſoul, for ever, ever loſt
in lake of death, Eternall death: Woo'd I
Had been deſtroyd within the houſe of ſin,
The curſed wombe, or been abortive born,
Ne're to have ſeen that hatefull light that ſees
My wretched fall.
Curſt be the fantacy that ſhap't the thought
Of my conception, ten times curſt the act?
The luſtfull act! ten thouſand times the hour
Of my nativity: may that ever be
An hour of horrour, plague, and miſery.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: For charity, good courteous Sir, take pitie on a poor diſtreſſed
Lady: Even for the love ye bear unto the womb that bred ye. She kne •

sp.speaker: Elea.
sp.l: The Love I bear? the love I bear is hate.
Hate moſt unatterable▪ ſo inveterate,
That I could curſe my primogenitors,
S • fut I could curſe my father Adam too.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: A laſs Sir I am rob'd and ſpoild of all.
Ah gentle Sir, afford me ſome relief,
And I will beg a bleſſing for your ſweet benevolence.

sp.speaker: Elea.
sp.l: Bleſſing for me? there's not a ſcruple left
Mongſt the great waight of heavenly charity,
Vex me no more.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: The Silent tamer of diurnall care •
That charms our weary limbs with ſweet repoſe,
Yields not relief to me? my wearied ſoul
Lives in perpetual torment; for if I
Chance to get a minutes reſt, my frighted Ghoſt
Sees ghaſtly Shapes? more horrible then death?
Even now mine eyes grow dull for want of ſleep:
Lie there diſtreſſed carcaſs, and forget
Thy ſelf to be in miſery.
sp.stage: Enter Perſiphone with the three furies, they Cir • le him about, and Pers •• phone Sings.

lg.l: FRom the infernal Kingdom wee
Come to read thy deſtinie:
Know thy hands imbru'd in blood
Muſt be bath'd in Stigian flood:
Mortall thou art damn'd for this
Endleſs ſhall thy torment be;
Horrour, plague and miſerie
Shall afflict thy ſooty ſoul,
Whilſt the tortur'd ſpirits howl,
Baniſht from eternall bliſs
Freezing cold and ſcorching fires
Shal reward thy ſoul deſires.
Loſs of heaven ſhall vex thee too
More then fire and froſt can do:
Whilſt the furious S • akes ſhall hiſs
Not a thouſand ages ſhall
Expiate thy bitter thrall?
Not a flood of tears aſſwage
Ought of thy enflamed rage
This thy doome for deeds amiſs
Muſick to thy meat ſhall be,
Damned fiends ſhal laugh at thee;
Laugh to ſcorn thy griping pain,
Laugh to hear thee curſe in va •••
Curſe thine endleſs miſeries.

sp.l: Ho, ho, ho, ho, ho, ho.

sp.speaker: Zareck.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, heres ſport alone for mee,
The murder of his father troubles him
With ghaſtly apparitions: horrour and deſpair
Purſue thy guilty ſoul, til I may ſee
My ful revenge in by calamity.
Agen, agen, agen, without I ſaw
The Furies here; the ſudden apparition
Has ſo appal'd my guilty ſoul, that I
Am loſt in terror; all my Vitals ſhrink
With ghaſtly fear, my intermiſſive pulſe
Speaks the diſorder of my panting heart:
No comfort for a poor diſtreſſed man!
Down, down rebellious knees; ſo ſtubborn ſtill!
I bear a burden of ſuch maſſie weight
Woo'd crack the mighty Axletree of Heaven,
Yet cannot force theſe ſturdy limbs to bend:
My Ovens mouth is damm'd with dirty ſin,
No vent for ſorrow; not a peeping-hole
To ſteal a dram of comfort for my ſoul.
O—Eleazer thou art loſt for ever.

div.head: ACTUS QUINTUS.

lg.l: WHat a Devil ails the General!
I have obſerv'd in him of late a ſtrange and uncouth
Carriage to his near attendants:
His looks diſtracted, and his words compos'd
With ſtrange diſturbance—Sure all it not well:
But I'le obſerve—

div.stage: Enter Titus, croſſes the ſtage, and exit with an angry look upon Valerio.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Death, what ſhould this mean?

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Valerio? Well met; ſaw'ſt thou the General lately?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Yes, I have ſeen him lately,
Heaven bleſs me from the ſight of him agen.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Why man, what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Whats the matter!
Why a has ſtar'd me into ſuch a ſtrange diſtemper,
I ſhall not be my ſelf this hour agen.
A looks—like Vulcan, when his fiery face
Looks red (with rage) upon the Rival God:
A walks—by ſembreeſs with ſuch ſtately gait,
As if a ſcorn'd to tread on Caſars Earth.
A ſpeaks—by riddles, and ſuch ſtrange enigmae's,
that ſure 'two'd poſe old Oedipus to anſwer.
Haſt not thou ſeen him in this muſty mood?

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.l: Yes, yes, yes, I have ſeen him, and ſelf him too,
Pox on's fingers for' • .
He askt me laſt night what ſtore was in the Magazine:
I told him—about a Months proviſion.
A ſteps him back—and ſtares—and ſtamps—and ſays—
What?—Is't poſſible?—No more?
Why doſt not ſpeak?—No more, I ſay?
Art ſure there is no more? Death woo't not ſpeak?
and then his truncheon walks; • 'fu • had I not warded we •
I had been mall'd, I knew not what to ſay;
And then a call'd me • o • , and went his way.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: Now by this hand I am lighter by a Roman dram,
to hear thee in for a ſhare too:
Why now I could ſing, or daunce,
Or rime, or jeſt, or do any thing.
Stand, ſtand thou here, and I will act the General.
And do thou ſpeak to me as if he were in preſence.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Content.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Nicanor!

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Come hither:
What ſtore of priſoners were taken in the skirmiſh

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: My Lord—

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.l: My Lord! what nothing • ut •• y Lord!
Souns, muſt I dance attendance on your anſwer.
Now ſir—what my Lord?—

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Souns, what d'ye ſtrike me.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: Fye, fye, vilely ſpoken, very vilely ſpoken,
Ask his Lordſhip why a ſtrikes?
Why this • avours of too much arrogance,
and woo'd incenſe him beyond meaſure:
Ye ſhould rather have ſaid, My Lord,
I am ſorry I have treſpaſt on your patience,
Or I crave your Lordſhips pardon for my du •• eſs,
Or the like.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.l: Pox a patience, and your Lordſhip too,
Why did ye ſtrike me ſo hard?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Out upon't, worſe and worſe by this light,
Limit his Lordſhip how hard to ſtrike!
Why this were to tell his Lordſhip what to do,
How to command, and where to puniſh:
this woo'd not be endur'd.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.l: I prethee leave thy jeſting,
Or by this light I ſhall fall out in earneſt,
and let your Lordſhip know I am diſpleaſed.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Well I have done; but prethee canſt thou tell
the cauſe of this diſtemper?
For in himſelf (what e're hath alter'd him)
He is a Captain of as mild a nature,
As brave Command, and of as ſweet converſe,
as Rome hath ever bred.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Faith I am ignorant, nor can I judge the cauſe. But—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Peace, the General.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.p: Valerio!

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: My Lord?

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: Come hither; nearer—yet nearer—nearer yet I ſay,
Souns, muſt I trumpet my Oration?
Or doſt thou think my throat's an Organ-pipe?
There has been lately a great out-rage done
within the Camp; know you ought of it?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Not I my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: Take heed I trap thee not, upon thy life take heed:
By Heaven if I do—
I ſay agen, there has been lately acted
A moſt inhumane murder—on the Jews—
the Captive Jews that fled to us for mercy;
Know'ſt thou ought yet?

sp.speaker: V.
sp.p: My Lord, I know not ought, nor ought have ever heard of this inhumane act.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.p: Nor you? why doſt not ſpeak? ſpeak I ſay. Death, if I ask agen—

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: My Lord, Nor I.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: Nor I!—what nor I?
Death, are ye ſo ſparing of your ſpeech ſir?
Take heed I do not frame an anſwer for thee;
By Heaven if I do, 'twill coſt thee dear the penning.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: My gracious Lord—

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.p: Comma.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: I am—

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.p: Comma.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Altogether—

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.p: Colon.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Ignorant—

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.p: Period. Troth I believe thee.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Of this proceeding:

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.p: What's all this put together now?

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: My Lord!

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: My contumelious Coxcomb,
Why was not this miſhapen anſwer given
without diſtraction? If thy ſoul be clear,
Why did thy guilty looks proclaim thee evil?
Why didſt thou vail the face of honeſty,
and innocence, within the mask of fear?
Thou wert begotten ſure in ſome diſtraction,
When Nature was diſturb'd to get a man:
Go—get thee hence, and get more Faith—but yet.
look to't, look to't I ſay, for if I find thee guilty,
thy life ſhall pay the ranſome of thy ſin:
Go—get thee hence—ſtay, read that,
and read it out.
sp.stage: A Catalogue of the Maſſacre of the Captive Jews, who fled to us for mercy.
sp.l: Vnder Valerio's Squadron, four hundred.
Vnder Nicanor's, five hundred.
Murdred out of the camp and ript for their Jewels
VVhich they had ſwallowed for fear of rifling eleven hundred;
The whole number amounting to two thouſand.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: This is ſtrange my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: Yes, 'tis wondrous ſtrange that we
Whoſe Princely-Valour, Power and Clemency
the world admires, ſhould be ſo foul abus'd,
Abus'd by you, by you I ſay abus'd,
And ſay't agen: Death—if, t • were not ſo,
who durſt attempt? attempt! durſt think to do
An act ſo foul, ſo moſt inhumane?
Have we not given the ſole command to you?
and you to do what you think fit?
And muſt we have our Honor now traduc't,
Trampled, and trod upon, through your neglect?
Muſt we, when we have paſt our princely word
For fair protection, have our Subjects ſnatcht
By ſuch diſcorder from our Princely boſom?
By heaven this is not well; I ſay it is not,
Look too't: look too't, I ſay, I hear no more of this,
For by a Romans honour if I do—go to I ſay, look too't:

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: Now by my life but this is wondrous ſtrange,
Two thouſand Jews deſtroi'd and we not know' ••

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.l: Tis ſo; nor can I blame the General.
To be diſtemperd. But now the ſtorm is over,
Let us by ſtrict inquiry ſearch the truth:
Perchance he may be miſ-inform'd, and we abuſ'd:

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: Content, let us about it.
sp.stage: Enter the Lady Miriam with a knife in her hand.
sp.l: How tedious are our daies of miſeries,
And yet how breefe the means to cut them off?
What multitudes of Wretched dayes and nights,
In whoſe each minute the affrighted ſoul
Lives on the wrack of grief and diſcontent,
W •• 'd this ſmal inſtrument of death diſpatch:
And why do I then; VVretched I, protract
My dayes of miſery?
I'ſt not enough that I have liv'd to ſee
My parents ſlain by native crueltie?
My countrey Sackt? and my religion Scorn'd,
My ſelf forſaken, and my ſtripling live
To ask me food, and I not food to give?
Can I have brains to know, and wil to do,
Reaſon to judge, and hands to help me too▪
And ſtill procraſtinate my daies of wo •
Doo't Miriam, doo't I ſay, it muſt be ſo:
VVhat iſt that barrocadoes back mine arm
Nor will, nor brain, nor heart, nor hand are mine;
All ſtand ſubjected to a power divine.
Tuſh—I am deceived;
Henceforward I nor God, nor good will know:
Religion is a thing fantaſticall,
And heaven and hell are meer Poeticall:
Hence coward fear, tis thou that doſt command
Mine arm to ſlack, thou makſt my ſhaking hand
Let fall the fatal inſtrument of death:
I will no more be ſubject to thy Law
But in a minute—
sp.stage: Goes to ſtab her ſelf agen
sp.l: Alas how cruell mercifull am I,
To free my ſelf from ſad calamity,
And leave my pretty child to ſuffer more,
Ile kill him firſt—and that once bravely done,
Ile kill the mother that has kild her ſon:
Now ſwift occaſion tempt us to do evil?
See where the ſtripling comes,
How pretily a looks upon me: and muſt I doeſt?
Was ever mother ſo unatural?
And yet I muſt.
My pretty boy: art thou not very ſick for want of meat?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Yes, very ſick indeed, and feeble too;
So feeble, I have much adoe to go.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Had'ſt thou not rather die, then live
In this extremity?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Alas good mother, I am loath to die,
I wood fain live to ſee you get ſome food.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: would'ſt therefore live, my boy, Why thou ſhalt be my food▪
When I have kill'd thee, I will feed on thee.

sp.speaker: Boy:
sp.l: Good God forbid ſuch Crueltie.
I hope you do not mean to kill me mother

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Yes, my ſweet Lamb, look; heres the knife prepar'd.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Nay then I ſee I ſhall be kill'd indeed:
Alaſs what have I done, what deed ſo foul
To make you ſo unkinde?
Indeed I did not think you could have been ſo cruell.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: How prettily a talks.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: have I forgotten ought of thoſe reſpects
That duty binds me too. Or through forgetfulneſs
Not done that ſervice which you did command;
Is this the cauſe? O hold, pray hold your hand:
My duty ſhall obſerve ye ten times more
Then ever my obedience did before.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: How hard a pleads for life; the Gentle Phraſe
Begins to mollifie my cruell breaſt.
In what a ſad dilemma ſtands my choiſe:
Affection bids me ſpare • affliction ſtrike:
Nor can I well approve? nor yet diſlike—
Of either—Something muſt be done:
Forgive me heaven, for I muſt kill my Son.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: O—I am Kill'd indeed, farewell.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: That well ſound's ill:—tis done—it may be no,
For ſtill a ſturs, and ſturs—but now tis done indeed:
Come take him up?—and Quarter him—and then
Invite the cruell Captain to a feaſt,
That they may ſee a mother eat her Son,
sp.stage: She takes him, up, and Exit.
sp.l: And kill her ſelf before the feaſt be done.
Come take him up I ſay.
sp.stage: Enter Eleazer with his ſleeves ſtript up to the Elbowes, with two Attendants following.
sp.l: I have waſht, and waſht, and waſht, and cannor waſh this blood away 〈◊〉

sp.speaker: Att.
sp.p: What blood my Lord.

sp.speaker: Elea.
sp.l: The blood of batts put out thine eyes:
Doo'ſt thou not ſee how red, and freſh it lookes?
Tis very not too: reaking hot; ſo hot
It Scaldes the cunduit pipes of life,
Fryes all my vitalls into Aetna's flames,
And makes a bonfire of my burning heart.
My Spoongy bellows that were wont to blow
Cool fannings to my bodies center,
Are Suffocate with Sulphrous heat▪ no crany left
To cool a tortur'd Soul.
Go fetch me Vulcans bellows, they'l doo't ſure;
Or—if not they,
I' •• force a paſſage through this houſe of clay,
and let in air

sp.speaker: Att.
sp.p: Lay hands upon him till the fit be paſt.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.l: Theſe flaming Lampes burn red with fury rage
To feel my marrow broil; my ſinged ſcull
Reverberates the fury to my brain,
And makes me mad. All this whole maſs of man
Is metamorphi • 'd to confuſion.
Hurry me ſtrait unto the Eolean cave,
That Boreas may bore me through and through
There ſhall ye ſee this active torrid Zone
Tug for the maſtry with the windy King;
That fire with air, and air with fire may burn,
Till fire and air do into Chaos turn.
sp.p: The devil ſure's a rare Doctor: of ancient ſtanding too. I'le have him ſent for, and — to bid him welcome a ſhall break his faſt with braines, twill be a rare breakfaſt, they are already frying in my ſcull. For—to have them cookt in a Kitchin-pan woo'd ſhew poor, and not Suit with his greatneſs? But let the Mercurian meſſenger make haſt, they will be fry'd too much elſe, and then all's not worth a button. Hark—hark—hark—how the furies laugh to ſee me tortur'd See—See—See▪ where they come from Erebus—There's Megara, Alecto, there Tiſiphone? ho ho ho ho: thats not ſhe, tis ſome baſtard fury made of Air to cheat my fancy. I am abuſed, Ile not indur't:
sp.l: Can your inky King
Cure my black ſoul? my ſoul, I there's the thing.

sp.speaker: Att.
sp.l: See now the • it is paſt
How temperate he walks. With what a ſerious eye
A views the heaven, and then the earth: and then
Himſelf with wonder: As if heaven and earth.
VVere there infuſed: See now a ſtarts agen,
I fear another fit.

sp.speaker: Elea.
sp.l: The ſoul's the thing indeed, this but a reaking dunghil:
Stay: what i'ſt made of? tis extracted ſure
From the pure Eſſence of refined air,
Puff'd—for when the wind is gone,
Commend me to the Car • ion carcaſs.
There's nothing left but meat for miſtreſs maggot.
Of your Philoſophers, give me Pythagoras,
For all the reſt are fools: meer fools: dee mark me Sir,
Why may not this ſame windy ſoul of mine,
Make muſick in a muſty midwife?
Or in a mouldy bawd: O—twood' do rare in her:
twoo'd make her mumpe out miſchiefs by the dozen:
Marry—of all your beaſts—I wood not be
A poſt horſe: Souns then I ſhould be trotted,
and trotted, and trotted to the devil:
No, no, no, Ile no poaſt horſe.
sp.stage: Enter his Fathers Ghoſt in white.
sp.l: Room, room, room for the miller:
Ma • now I think ont, tis as bad to be mil horſe:
For he goes round about, and round about,
And round about—

sp.speaker: Ghoſt.
sp.l: Fool: thou art poſting to the ſtage of death!
Adiew, adiew, adiew: expect thy doom.

sp.speaker: Eleaz.
sp.l: by this light a rare miller.
Wo, ho, ho, wo, ho, ho: Miller, Miller.

sp.speaker: Atten.
sp.p: We muſt not leave him.

div.stage: Enter Jehocanan and Simeon upon the Walls:

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: their valour yet lives freſh within the walls:
They man the breaches bravely.

sp.speaker: Je.
sp.l: Call ye this valour, meer dunghil cocks by heaven,
S •• ut, put a Coward in the face of death,
Extremity of fear will make him fight,
Fight Valiantly too. Give me the man
That mans a breach in breaking through the rancks
Of Romans foes, their Courages diſmaid,
the walls will man themſelve:

div.stage: A trumpet ſounds, and Enter Joſeph in Compleat Arms:

sp.speaker: Jo
sp.l: My honored Lords, and deereſt Countrymen,
From the right noble Titus I am come
to Offer mercy. Ah! my worthy friends,
Even on my knees I beg you to imbrace it.

sp.speaker: Jeho.
sp.p: Bring forth the rack and torture the old r • ffin.
sp.stage: Gorion brought out and put on the rack:

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: hold—hold—O hold. Let not your fury fall
On thoſe decreppid lims, for heavens ſake hold,
And here but Joſeph ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Torture him I ſay.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.l: Tortures and torments endleſs vex your Souls:
O hold—yet hold, for heavens love hold, not yet:
Muſt I indure to ſee thoſe Sinews ſtrecht,
And not relieve them Muſt I baſely beg,
And kneel? and ſupplicate: and not be heard?
Wrack on—wrack on I ſay! thou cruell wretch:
Tear the diſtreſſed Carcaſs from the ſoul,
And ſend it up to heaven to cry for vengeance:
Agen they torture him. O I am tortured too,
And torne in peices with the ſpectacles.
Villains, tormentors, Rebells.
sp.stage: they beat him down with a ſtone.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Forſake the walls, and take him.

div.stage: Enter Jehochanan and Simeon at one door, and Valerio and Nicanor as another, they repulſe the Jewiſh Captains, and Joſeph riſeth.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.p: How fares Joſephus?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Hurt my good friends, I thank you for this reſcue
sp.stage: they lead him away and Exeunt
sp.l: Lord Elazer's mad: there's my revenge on him.
A comes, a comes:
Now the ſport begins.
My conſcience is a bawling curr?
Buz, buz, buz: Hee's gone, hee's gone?
Ile, creep, and creep, and creep away,
And then I'le laugh to think how I have gulld him.
Whiſt; whiſt, whiſt, and catch a mouſe.

sp.speaker: Za.
sp.p: My Lord?

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: For heavens love help me, Zareck:

sp.speaker: Za.
sp.p: Why, what's the matter now?

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: O vengeance, I am peſterd with a Raſcal beyond meaſure: And knocks, and knocks, and knocks, both day and night to ſpeak with me, and will have no denyal.

sp.speaker: Za.
sp.p: VVho i'ſt, who i'ſt my Lord?

sp.speaker: E.
sp.l: A Sooty fellow, black, exceeding black:
And wonderous lean too. Very lean, and hungry.
And but e'ne now I ſtole, and ſtole away:
Could ye but get a truce for ſome:—three dayes,
VVe woo'd be wonderous merry, Zareck:

sp.speaker: Za.
sp.l: Methinks we ſhould prevail:
Let's ſooth him in this humour, and we ſhall have excellent ſport anon.

sp.speaker: Atten.
sp.p: Content, content:

sp.speaker: Za.
sp.p: My Lord, I'le warrant ye, let me alone to deal with him.

sp.speaker: El:
sp.l: Ye muſt be wondrous earneſt, for I tell ye, he's a peſtilent knave:
Tell him at three days end. I'l hear him all;
Mean while. I'le hide me here:
ſt' ſt ſt: Zareck: if a aſk for me,
Be ſure thou doſt not tell him where I am.
Stand cloſe. ſtand cloſe. hah. whats that.

sp.speaker: Att.
sp.p: A ratt behinde the hangings.

sp.speaker: Elea.
sp.p: A comes, a comes, a comes.

sp.speaker: Att.
sp.p: Be not afraid my Lord; tis Zareck comes:

sp.speaker: Za.
sp.p: Tis done my Lord I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: For three whole dayes.

sp.speaker: Za.
sp.p: For three whole dayes.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: And nights.

sp.speaker: Za.
sp.p: And nights.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.l: Gramerrcy boy, Ifaith.
There were three fidlers at a fray,
For ſcraping of their ſtrings in tway,
And jenkin jobſon ran away,
With hay tralolly lolly.
Methinkes it were a rare thing to be a Jig-maker.
Come ſhall wee dance-ſhall we dance? hay-hay.

sp.speaker: 2 Att.
sp.p: Certainly a will fall into as much extremity of mirth.

sp.speaker: Za.
sp.p: I told ye wee ſhould have rare ſport anon.

sp.speaker: E
sp.l: Excellent good Ifaith, twill do paſſing well.
Hark ye boyes, hark ye. I have excellent crotchets in my head.

sp.speaker: Za.
sp.p: What be they, what be they?

sp.speaker: E.
sp.l: Muſical, muſical crotchets, my bullyes;
And therefore I'l have a noiſe of fidlers dwell there
To run diviſion? wilt not do rare my boyes?

sp.speaker: Za.
sp.p: O paſſing rare my Lord.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: Vory good, and then—

sp.speaker: 1 Att.
sp.p: What then.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.l: And then will I turn ballet ſinger.
You ſhall carry my pack, and you
I'l think of ſome imployment whorthy your deſerts.
Will not this be fine Ifaith? hah. ſpeak.

sp.speaker: 2 Att.
sp.p: very fine, very fine.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: And then wee'l ſing, and laugh conſcience out of countenance; Fare yo well: fare ye wel, my boys.

sp.speaker: Za.
sp.l: If a ſhould meet his conſcience by the way now,
We ſhould have an old racket with him.

sp.speaker: 1 Att.
sp.p: No, no, hee'l be wholly taken vp now with making ditties, Moſt inexpreſſible ditties, we ſhal have ſuch fuſtian we meet him next

sp.speaker: 2 Att.
sp.p: Death, I'l lay my life 'tis he.

sp.speaker: Za.
sp.l: Did not I prejudicate the iſſue?
What will become of us now?
What ſhall we do?

sp.speaker: Elea.
sp.p: Ope the door, ope the door, ye muſty raſcalls.

sp.speaker: Att.
sp.l: If we ope not the door hee'l break it ope,
And then a will be ten times worſe.

sp.speaker: Za.
sp.l: Stay, is there no trick to pacify his fury?
Hum—I have found out one I think will doo't.

sp.speaker: Att.
sp.p: What i'ſt: what i'ſt?

sp.speaker: Za.
sp.p: There dwells a fellow not far off:

sp.speaker: Elea.
sp.p: Rake-hells: hell hounds: ope the door.

sp.speaker: Att.
sp.p: By and by:

sp.speaker: Za.
sp.l: Whoſe Meager looks will ſurely couzen him:
He is in all deſcription like his conſcience:
A wears black too, him wee'l produce faſt bound
To give him ſatisfaction.

sp.speaker: Elea.
sp.p: Rogues, Raſcalls, Cheaters:

sp.speaker: Za.
sp.p: Come ope the doors, ope the door.

sp.speaker: Za.
sp.p: Why how now my Lord, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: My conſcience ſlaves: my conſcience.

sp.speaker: Za.
sp.p: Has a been at home; has a been at home ſince?

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: You, you, you, know a has: You know a has raſcalls.

sp.speaker: Za.
sp.l: O perfidious conſcience, how did a ſwear to us
Not to molleſt him till the time expir'd.
My Lord, my Lord, have but a little patience,
And if I bring him not faſt bound—

sp.speaker: E.
sp.l: 'Vm—if you do not bandogs
Nay, nay, nay; you ſhall be pawn'd for the reckoning:
I, I, I, wil ſo Jerk ye, if a brings him not,
I will have thee cut out into a town-top, and whipt;
And—Petruſio • s Skin ſhall make ſcourges.

sp.speaker: Att.
sp.l: Any thing: any thing my Lord: do with me what ye will:
But woo'd I were fairly quit: pray heaven they bring the fellow.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: Nay, nay, nay, I wool doo't, and to purpoſe too.

sp.speaker: Att.
sp.p: See, ſee my lord: ſee where a comes.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: Hah: is a faſt: is a faſt bound?

sp.speaker: Att.
sp.p: I warrant ye, fear not.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: Look too't?

sp.speaker: Za.
sp.p: come foreward man, fear nothing.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Why do's a gape ſo, will a not bite?

sp.speaker: Za.
sp.p: No, no, no, I warrant thee,

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: I am peſlance affraid of my noſe it hangs but by the Skin.
If a ſhould but touch it 'twere utterly loſt.

sp.speaker: Elea.
sp.p: Fury, why doſt thou hunt me?

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.p: What muſt I ſay now?
Say, for food.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: For food.

sp.speaker: Eleaz
sp.p: For food? what food will 〈◊〉 thy hungry 〈◊〉 ?

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Let me alone to anſwer now? Pouderd-beef.

sp.speaker: Elea.
sp.p: I will have him ſhut up a Cr • mming, wilt not do well Zareck?

sp.speaker: Za.
sp.p: Exceeding well▪

sp.speaker: Elea.
sp.p: And then I will make him a chopping boy
O rare! does a ſpeak in earneſt • ow?

sp.speaker: Elea.
sp.p: Petruſio: I will have him • ed with chopt hay. And then I will cut him out in ſteaks for my breakfaſt.

sp.speaker: Pet:
sp.p: A had better feed upon C • w-beef for I ſhall eat monſtrous tuff.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: Away with him Zareck; ho, ho, ho, I have him faſt now. I'ſt Petruſio:

sp.speaker: Att.
sp.p: My Lord?

sp.speaker: E.
sp.l: Feed him with a Pitchlork, l •• ſt a bite th •• by the fingers.
Ho, ho, ho, I have caught the woodcock in a •• ring.
sp.stage: A table brought out, and ſpread, and Enter Peter.
sp.l: We have rare cheer towards Ifaith,
And I am monſterous ſharp ſet,
But I am peſtelence affraid of theſe ſame hungry Captains;
If they ſhould invite themſelves to dinner now,
What woo'd become of me?
Heres one come already, Ile lay my life on't,
Who knocks there?

sp.speaker: Ie.
sp.p: Ope the door, ſirrah.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.l: Tis he; tis he: I kn • w him by his terrible voice:
Madam madam lady madam;
Heres my lord Iochy come agen.

sp.speaker: Ie.
sp.p: Ope the door I • ay.

sp.speaker: Pe:
sp.p: By and by▪

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: now is the edg of • ine appeti • e as d •• as a beetle.
Hay, hay • eres a whole rabblement of captains:
Why madam-lady.
I muſt ope the door, or 〈◊〉 they'l break my pa • e agen.

sp.speaker: Ie.
sp.p: Roſt-meat; roſt-meat-I ſmel roſt-meat.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.p: Pox a your quick ſent.-, by and by.
sp.stage: Knocks agen, and opens the door.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Death, I am almoſt ſtarv'd. A ſhare, a ſhare.
I cry a ſhare, this fellow ſmells of fa • ,
Of pretious • at; firrah confeſs, confeſs.

stage.hi: they draw: Laye • hold on him

sp.l: What haſt thou 〈◊〉 to •• ys
Thou ſme ••• of roaſt-meat: •• ave, where i • t▪
Where 'iſt I ſay? for I wool have it all.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.l: They'l eat me up between um ſure.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.p: Thou ſha' • take me too then: Raſcal, go fetch it me.

sp.speaker: P.
sp.l: If they don't eat me up, they'l pull me in peeces.
Oh—Oh—I wool Sir, I wool Sir.

div.stage: Enter Eleazer with his rapier drawn.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.p: Give me ſome food, you hungry Canniballs.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.p: Heres another, here's another.

sp.speaker: Ie.
sp.p: Keep off thou frantick fool.

sp.speaker: Pe.
sp.p: Why Madam, Lady; look to the Roſt-meat▪ the Captains; the captains.

sp.speaker: Ie.
sp.p: Minion Come down; come down I ſay, or by my life Ile fetch thee down.

sp.speaker: L:
sp.l: Mir. Patience my Lord I pray, and you ſhall ſee
That Miriam has reſerv'd a part for you;
A plenteous part, enough to feaſt ye all.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.l: There ſtands the queen of heaven: what ho! Ch • h • a.
Bring forth the bak't meats: Come, Lords ſit ye down,

div.l: Ile feed ye with ſuch Cates ſo rare, and delicate,
And of ſuch ſturring nature, you will wonder,
When you ſhal feel their powerfull operation.
See? theres a hand for you; for you a foot;
For you my Lord the heart, the p • e • ious heart.
Now-good my Lords fall to; fall to I pray.

sp.speaker: Elea.
sp.p: The heart is raw-and bloudy, Ile not eat it: It ſtur • s-it ſtur • s.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: What ſtur • ?

sp.speaker: Elea.
sp.p: My fathers heart, Ile not endure to • ee;'t.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: I have a monſtrous quame come over my ſtomack now.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: What; not a bitt my Lord▪ Ah, my beloved ſonn!
How ſweet and pleaſing was thy Company,
Whilſt thou wert yet a live? and even in death,
Thou ſtill art ſweet and pretious; for by thee
Theſe Cruell, Captains are be • ome my friends,
By the I am ſuſtain'd and kept alive.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I am amaz'd:

sp.speaker: Ie.
sp.p: Far • the • well, thou 〈◊〉 woman •

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: For ſhame my Lords, let nor a womans heart
Out-brave a ſoldiers: dare ye not • aſte a bit?
Waſ't not your Cruelty that cau •• d me kill him?
And will ye then refuſe to eat apart?

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.l: Now have I a conceit, that ſome thing ſturrs in my belly.
I am in travail ſure: fo my 〈◊〉 wambles and wambles,
And I ſhall be deliver'd on't e • e long.

div.stage: Drums beat, and they fight within.

sp.speaker: E.
sp.l: where art thou Caeſar, where art thou Caeſar?
Ile ſight with none but Caeſar.
Here comes Achilles, brave Achilles:
O—I am fal'n for Ever.

sp.speaker: Ie.
sp.p: Give fire to the Temple; give fire to the Temple:

stage.hi: The Temple fir'd • and enter Titus.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.l: Forbear; forbear, ye curſed wretches; to deſtroy
Thoſe ſacred walls,—how glorious they appear!
O ye rebellious Slaves! how dare ye tempt
So Great a Deity? By all the gods it burns, it burns▪
The raving fire has ſeiz'd the battlements.
Horrors and vengeance, plagues and punniſhments
Seiz on your ſtubborn ſouls; it burns, it burns afreſh;
The heavens are angry ſure, they • hi • e with me.
Forbear-Forbear, thou flaming firmament,
To chide Veſpatians ſonn; for tis not he
Hath done thee this diſhonor.

div.stage: Thunder: Enter Simion, his rap: drawn, with a robe and a crown vnder his arms.

sp.speaker: S.
sp.l: Sure the black mantle of the M • mphitiſts,
That muzled once the face of Egypt aire:
The dreadfull darkneſs of Cimmerian foggs,
Whoſe neighbour nation to the frozen pole,
For ever's baniſht from the Glimps of light:
Nor hel it ſelf, nor ought, (if ought there be).
More dark then hell, can be more horrible.
Then is this dreadfull night, this night of death.
I heard a mighty voice within the Temple cry,

l.hi: Come away, come away; Let us depart from hence.

sp.l: Strange apparitions have been ſeen by many:
Sure Heaven, and Earth, and hell have all conſpir'd
Our ruin. I am a maz'd. within this darkeſome dale
There is a ſecret cave will ſhelter me.
Tis here this ſtrange diſguiſe perchance may ſave my life.

stage.hi: Feels about, and Enter • the cave

sp.l: This way, or that, I know not which to take▪
I am perfued one every ſide, I will take this.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: The two Seditious Captains are eſcape,
But ſure they cannot long conceal themſelves.
Extremity of hunger will betray them.
Where is the Generall?

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.l: Retreating to his tent, and wondrous ſad
To ſee the ruins of the Sacred Temple.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: Hee's of a noble nature; prethy Nicanor
Let us invent ſome pleaſing way
To Cure him of his diſcontent.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.l: With all my heart: let us preſent the Maske
We late intended.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.p: Happily thought of; we • will ha' • e to night.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Content; content.

div.stage: Enter Simeon out of the Cave, with a Robe vpon him, and a Crown on his head.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.p: Defend me heaven! what apparition's that?

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Hah:—let's ſpeak to it.

sp.speaker: Simi.
sp.l: Extremity of hunger has compel'd
Me to reveal my ſelf:
This ſtrange diſguiſe perchance may ſave my life:
The Romans are afraid.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: A beckons us; let us go near:
What art thou, that doſt wear thoſe Kingly Robes?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: I am of Sacred Linage Romans;
Sprung from the Kings of Iuda; ſhelter'd here
To ſave my life. Conduct me to your Lord the General.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.l: Lay hands upon him: Now by my life tis Simeon.
Come Villain, wee'l conduct thee to the General.

sp.speaker: Va.
sp.l: Now By this hand this prize was finely caught:
sp.stage: Exeunt, and drag him along two follow
sp.l: This wool pleaſe Titus well.

div.stage: Enter a Drum cover'd with black, beating a ſad Retreat; with black pendants: Than enter Titus, Gorion, and Joſeph, with attendants.

sp.speaker: Titus.
sp.l: Come good old man, now on a Romans word
Thou art welcome, nobly welcome:
Come ſit down, ſit there; nay I will have it ſo.
• ruſt me I joy to ſe thee ſafe at liberty.

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.l: Thanks to my honor'd Lord.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.p: How fares thy aged Wife?

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.l: Shee's well, my gracious Lord,
But ſomewhat weak with long impriſonment.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: O my Joſephus! how I grieve to ſee
the ruines of they fair Jeruſalem:
But as it is, I give the ſacred power
to be diſpos'd by thee.

sp.speaker: Joſ.
sp.p: Thanks, my moſt honored Lord.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.p: Thy Father it grown old, and will deſire to ſpend his days in peace.
What means that Muſick?

div.stage: Exit Joſeph and comes in agen.

sp.speaker: Joſ.
sp.p: Thy Captains, gracious Prince, deſire to ſhew thee ſome paſtime.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.p: We do accept it, give them entrance: 'twill relliſh well to paſs our diſcontent.

div.head: THE MASQVE.
div.stage: Enter Time bearing an Eſcutcheon, 〈◊〉 Roman Champions crown'd with Lawrel follow, each bears an Eſcutcheon: Jehochanan and Simeon follow guarded: Time preſents his Eſcutcheon to the General.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: What's here? ſix Roman Champions leading the world captive: the Motto: Not one; but all: ſubſcrib'd.
Times winged ſpeed doth here preſent
Six Moral Virtue's fair Event.
Six Roman Champions, whilſt they live,
to theſe Six Virtues harbour give.

div.stage: The Champions preſent their Eſcutcheons in order.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.p: Piety pourtraied in a black Man ••• , in her left hand a S • or • an Embleme of reciprocal love, her right arme ſtretcht over an Altar, with a ſword in her hand, to shew her reſolution for Religion: the Motto, Semper ea ••• .
sp.l: Your inventions have done well to give this Virtue priority,
For 'tis the Baſis of our glorious actions:

the firm foundation that our
〈◊〉
laid
When firſt a did ordain the Veſtal-fires:
It would have been more proper had ye limm'd her
Smiling, and pointing to a ſumptuous houſe
Built on the rowling land: the Motto this,
Sine me peris Impenſa: well, the next.
sp.p: Temperance decipher'd in a white Robe, with a ſober countenance, in her left hand a Cornucopia, with this Motto, In abundanti • abſte • io: the next.
Chaſtity pictur'd in a green Robe, a Lion couching by her ſide, she points to a Lilly: the Mooto, Pares nos ſumus.
Friendſhip binding a fardle of ſticks together: the Motto, Concordio regna florent.
Conſtancy depainted in a purple Robe, her left hand pointing to the Moon, her right to her Boſom: the Motto, Mutabile qui • quid extra, nil imus.
Patience limm'd in a Violet Robe, pointing to—mee: Hah, it's not ſo? 'tis ſo: the Motto, Diſpares nos ſumus, and under, Sa • ciro 〈◊〉 ſat bent;
sp.l: This was a good conceit, it likes me paſſing well:
For now I ſee, my Lords, yee will not flatter me:
Well, I'le indevour to amend it, Lord:
Come, now to your ſports.

div.stage: Muſick, and they dance: the Mask ended, Time preſents the Priſoners, and exeunt.

sp.speaker: Jehoch.
sp.p: Mercy, my gracious Lord▪

sp.speaker: Titus.
sp.p: What ſtately Priſoner's he • , that wears the Diadem.

sp.speaker: Je.
sp.p: My honor'd Lord, this is the cruel Simeon; And this Jehochanan.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.p: What! art ſure tis he?

sp.speaker: Je.
sp.p: Moſt certain, mighty Prince.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Mercy, my honor'd Lord.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: Look down, look down, ye powers above, and ſee
the baſeſt ſcum of all mortality,
Is't poſſible to ſee the Villains kneel,
And beg?
Seaven daies together let the Slaves be led
And each day tortur'd to extremity,
then put them to an ignominious death.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Curſes and plagues reward thee.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.p: Now worthy Gorion thou haſt liv'd to ſee thy ſelf reveng'd of all thine injury,

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.p: Ah my good Lord! I joy not in revenge, that I muſt leave to heaven.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.p: Enquire the cauſe of that ſhout.

sp.speaker: 1. Attendant.
sp.p: More priſoners brought, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.p: Let them have entrance▪

div.stage: Enter Officers leading Zareck and the Lady Miriam Priſoners, another following leading Peter with an haſte • about his neck, the Lady weeps.

sp.speaker: 1. Officer.
sp.p: Come along Sir, Come along • you have no ſtomach to go too't.

I have more ſtomach beha' • e to eat, if I had ſome vittail • hark ye Sir, pray do not pull too hard, leaſt ye pull my head off; it's held on by nothing but skin and dry bones, the marrow is waſted long ſince; I believe I ſhall never hold the han ••• g.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.p: What Lady's that, whoſe ſad behaviour ſpeaks ſuch diſcontents

sp.speaker: Gor.
sp.l: Ah Noble Titus, to relate the ſtory
Of her ſad fate, will prove a task too weighty
For a woful breaſt to utter—
Let others ſpeak her ſad calamity,
For me it is enough to weep her miſery.

sp.speaker: Titus.
sp.l: Riſe up diſtreſſed woman: by all that's good,
I joy not in ſo ſad a ſpectacle.
Tell me thy cauſe of grie • ance: If there be
A way to make thee happy, leave it to me,
And I will ſee thee righted.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: A way to make me happy? ay the poor wretch:
the world to me is a diſtaſtfull thing,
Full of affrighting Objects: penſive thoughts and fears,
Horrors, amazements, anguiſh, greefe and • ears,
Attend my reſtleſs hours: no room is left
For the leaſt hope of comfort: no ſtarting hole
to eaſe the torture of a wearied ſoul.

sp.speaker: Ti.
sp.p: Know'ſt thou this Lady, Ioſeph.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: My honor'd Lord, this is the Lady Miriam •
Extracted from a noble family:
the ſad Epitome of grief and miſery:
the wofull mother of a murther'd? ſon.

sp.speaker: Titus.
sp.p: Murther'd? by whom?

sp.speaker: Lady Miriam.
sp.p: By me, by this accurſed arme, en • ombed here within the wretched womb that gave it life.

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: Me thinks I feel a great 〈◊〉 ſtir in my ſtomack •• w.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Ah my dear ſon! thy wounds bleed freſh
In my remembrance: the bloudy act
Si •• ſad upon my ſoul •••• ghts my guilty breaſt,
Diſtracts my working brain: Iuſtice, my Lord:
I cry for Juſtice againſt my cruel 〈◊〉

And muſt not be den • e •
〈◊〉

sp.speaker: Titus.
sp.l: The vnpleaſing Spectacle diſturbs me,
Lead her away, and ſee her ſ • f • ly kept,
And gently vſ'd; let war •• ſt eyes
Attend her actions, leaſt ſhe offer
Violence to her unhappy ſelf▪

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Were I at liberty for that, I would not linger out
a moment I hate to live, and yet I feel to dy
By mine own hand • for Heavens love • et me—

sp.speaker: Titus
sp.p: Leadher away; and comfort her.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Ah! be not ſo vnkind: can ye 〈◊〉 pi •• y ſee a Ca •• iffon the wrack of miſery, and not relieve her.

sp.speaker: Gorion.
sp.p:
Paſſion I • ear will over co •
〈◊〉 , if ſhe perſiſt in this extremity.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
Open a paſſage to my guilty ſoul, and ſend it to eternal vengeance—or if there be one drop of mercy le ••
〈◊〉 miſery, 〈◊〉
• o heaven to begg it—

sp.speaker: Titus.
sp.p: My ſoul relents to ſee 〈…〉 A

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.l: Thats old gray-beard, that was led a way
by me to tortures, if he remembers me,
I go to pot: 'ſt Madam, Lady, Madam,
Speak a good word for me.

sp.speaker: Titus.
sp.p: What's he that wears that livery of Death?

sp.speaker: Gorion.
sp.l: A ſervant to the Lady Miriam, the very ſame
that led my aged limbs to torture,
but by cumpulſion of the rebel Iews:
I therefore humbly beg his pardon.

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: I, I, I, muſt to't, now a has ſpy'd me.

sp.speaker: Titus.
sp.p: Come hither ſirrah.

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: Now I go, now I go, now I go, Lady, madam:

sp.speaker: Titus.
sp.l: Although I know thee to be guilty of an offence
Deſerving death; yet for thy Ladies ſake,
And this good man's, I give thee life and liberty:
Looſe him, and leave him to his lady's ſervice:
See thou be careful of her preſervation.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Ay me moſt miſcrable.

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.l: O rare! now could I leap out of my skin for Joy.
Come away Madam, come a way:
the ſight of the halter makes my ſtomack wamble.
Come away, I ſay.

sp.speaker: Zareck.
sp.l: A ha, ha, ha, ha; Confuſion play thy part,
And hatch up miſchief to the higheſt ſtrain
Of mans invention.

sp.speaker: Titus.
sp.l: What daring priſoner's he,
Whoſe uncouth laughter ſcorns at miſery?

sp.speaker: Ioſephus.
sp.l: The moſt unheard of piece of villany
that ever Nature gave a being to:
this is that curſed wretch that blew the coles
Of hot diſſention 'twixt the Citizens:
that murdred the high Prieſt, and promted on
the three ſeditious Captains to ambition;
that rob'd this wretched Lady, and gave fire
to Jewries ſacred temple.

sp.speaker: Titus.
sp.l: Villain, What ſaiſt thou for thy ſelf?
Is all this true?

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: A broke my pate too:

sp.speaker: Za.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.—all this! all this and ten times more
all this is nothing, not the thouſand part
Of my unknown deſigns: did'ſt thou but know
the danger that is in me, thou wouldſt not venture me
So near thy perſon.

sp.speaker: Titus.
sp.l: Halter him, and lead him to the wrack.
Let him be tortur'd with the greateſt rigour
Can be invented.

sp.speaker: Za.
sp.l: Ha ha ha ha—Could'ſt thou deviſe
As many tortures as have e're bin born
By all the ſons of Adam; thus wood I ſlight
Both them and thee.—

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: I ſhall unmask this helliſh bravery:
Lead him away, I ſay,

sp.speaker: Zar.
sp.l: Thou canſt not, Roman, in ſpight of cruelty,
Zareck will triump in the Victory.

sp.speaker: Officers.
sp.p: Come along Sir, come along.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Hark yee Sir, when ye begin to cry Oh—
Remember whoſe pate yee broke, Sir.

sp.speaker: Zar.
sp.p: Peace, Babler.

sp.speaker: Tit.
sp.l: Come honor'd friends, upon a Romans word
Ye're nobly welcome: let not Jewrys fall
Diſmay your Princely hearts: Romes General
Will find a way to raiſe your ruin'd State.
The gods are juſt; we muſt ſubmit to fate:
Take care of that diſtreſſed Lady.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Now do I long to ſee the Captains at it.

div.head: EPILOGVS.
div.l: THE lofty Buskin, and the learned Bay,
Are not exſpected to adorn our Play;
Our Author d •• meth theſe fair trophies fi •
To grace the raptures of a riper wit.
The ſtately lines of Sophocles high ſtrain
Flow from the fountain of Minerva's brain •
Inſtead of Bayes, and Buskins, if our ſtile
May fairly merit your deſerved ſmile;
'Tis all we aime as; either grant us this,
Or gently pardon what you judge amiſs.
